content.text: However, these licenses may also impose obligations such as for example a requirement that modifications to the code that are distributed must be made available in source code form, requirement to include copyright notices, requirements on how software can be redistributed, or requirement to freely release the combined software code (incorporating the open source code).

content.verbatim_text: Because of the nature of OSS, any modifications to the any OSS code must be considered carefully by Zebracorp IPR.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's IPR department must carefully consider any modifications made to Open Source Software code.
content.expert_insight: Modifying OSS, especially 'copyleft' licenses like GPL, carries significant risks of inadvertently triggering viral clauses. Careful IPR review is essential to prevent unintended disclosure of proprietary code or non-compliance.
content.conditions: Applies to any modifications made to OSS code.
content.justification: Mandates a specific internal process ('must be considered carefully') for risk mitigation related to IP.
content.implication_company: Obligation for Zebracorp IPR to conduct thorough reviews; risk of IP contamination if not handled carefully.
content.implication_supplier: No direct implication for supplier.
content.source_insight: Emphasizes the inherent risks associated with modifying OSS, particularly due to its 'nature'.
content.text: Because of the nature of OSS, any modifications to the any OSS code must be considered carefully by Zebracorp IPR.

content.verbatim_text: Modifications to the GPL code are generally not possible.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should generally avoid modifying GPL (GNU General Public License) code.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical warning. GPL's strong copyleft nature means that any derived work, including modifications, must also be licensed under GPL, effectively making proprietary modifications open source. This is usually unacceptable for commercial products.
content.conditions: Applies specifically to GPL code.
content.justification: Highlights a near-prohibition due to the severe 'viral effect' of GPL, which can compromise Zebracorp's proprietary IP.
content.implication_company: Strong prohibition against modifying GPL code to protect proprietary IP; risk of 'viral effect' if ignored.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should avoid incorporating GPL code into components that Zebracorp intends to modify or combine with proprietary code.
content.source_insight: Directly states a practical impossibility for commercial entities due to GPL's terms.
content.text: Modifications to the GPL code are generally not possible.

content.verbatim_text: In that case, we should specifically state that nothing contained in those open source license terms will restrict the rights granted to Zebracorp under the agreement.
content.plain_text: When OSS license terms take precedence over the main agreement's license grant, Zebracorp must explicitly state that OSS terms do not restrict Zebracorp's rights under the main agreement.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial protective measure. While accepting OSS license precedence for the *license grant*, Zebracorp must ensure its broader contractual rights (e.g., use, sublicensing, indemnities) are not inadvertently curtailed by the OSS terms.
content.conditions: Applies when negotiating that OSS license terms take precedence over the license grant of the mutual agreement.
content.justification: Mandates a specific contractual safeguard to protect Zebracorp's rights, mitigating risks from conflicting license terms.
content.implication_company: Obligation to include specific protective language in agreements; preserves Zebracorp's rights under the main agreement.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier must accept this carve-out to ensure Zebracorp's rights are maintained.
content.source_insight: Provides a specific negotiation tactic to balance OSS license precedence with Zebracorp's contractual rights.
content.text: In that case, we should specifically state that nothing contained in those open source license terms will restrict the rights granted to Zebracorp under the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: So while we accept the license restrictions that come with the OSS, the supplier of the code should make sure that those restrictions do not conflict with the licenses and rights that it has granted to Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: The supplier must ensure that any restrictions from OSS licenses do not conflict with the licenses and rights granted by the supplier to Zebracorp under the main agreement.
content.expert_insight: This shifts the burden of managing OSS license conflicts onto the supplier, ensuring that Zebracorp's negotiated rights are not undermined by the supplier's choice to incorporate OSS.
content.conditions: Applies when Zebracorp accepts OSS license restrictions.
content.justification: Imposes a clear obligation on the supplier to prevent conflicts that would negatively impact Zebracorp's contractual rights.
content.implication_company: Right to receive code where OSS restrictions are consistent with supplier grants; protection against conflicting terms.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to review and manage OSS licenses to ensure compatibility with grants to Zebracorp; potential liability if conflicts arise.
content.source_insight: Clarifies the division of responsibility regarding OSS license compatibility.
content.text: So while we accept the license restrictions that come with the OSS, the supplier of the code should make sure that those restrictions do not conflict with the licenses and rights that it has granted to Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: As for all terms and conditions other than license terms, our position should be that the terms of our mutual agreement will apply also to the OSS components of a particular product.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's position is that all terms and conditions of the mutual agreement, other than specific license terms, apply to OSS components within a product.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical negotiation stance to ensure that general contractual protections like warranties, indemnities, and liability caps extend to the entire product, including its OSS parts, preventing suppliers from disclaiming responsibility for OSS.
content.conditions: Applies to all terms and conditions other than the specific license grant/restrictions of the OSS itself.
content.justification: Establishes a strong negotiation position to ensure comprehensive contractual coverage for OSS components, protecting Zebracorp's interests.
content.implication_company: Right to enforce all contractual terms (e.g., warranties, indemnities) against the supplier for OSS components.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to accept that general contractual terms apply to OSS components, increasing their responsibility.
content.source_insight: Defines Zebracorp's preferred contractual position for non-license terms related to OSS.
content.text: As for all terms and conditions other than license terms, our position should be that the terms of our mutual agreement will apply also to the OSS components of a particular product.

content.verbatim_text: This means that in e.g. the IPR indemnity that protects us against third party infringement claims applies also the OSS components.
content.plain_text: The IPR indemnity protecting Zebracorp against third-party infringement claims must apply to all OSS components.
content.expert_insight: IPR indemnity is paramount. OSS, despite being 'free,' is still copyrighted and can be subject to infringement claims. Ensuring the supplier indemnifies Zebracorp for OSS components is crucial to mitigate this significant risk.
content.conditions: Applies to IPR indemnity clauses in agreements.
content.justification: Directly states a critical protection (IPR indemnity) must cover OSS, addressing a major legal risk.
content.implication_company: Right to be indemnified by the supplier for IPR infringement claims related to OSS components.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to indemnify Zebracorp for IPR infringement claims arising from OSS components.
content.source_insight: Provides a specific example of a critical term that must extend to OSS components.
content.text: This means that in e.g. the IPR indemnity that protects us against third party infringement claims applies also the OSS components.

content.verbatim_text: The supplier’s election to incorporate OSS components into its products should not limit the warranties and indemnities available to Zebracorp under the agreement.
content.plain_text: A supplier's decision to use OSS components in its products must not limit the warranties and indemnities Zebracorp receives under the agreement.
content.expert_insight: This is a non-negotiable point. Suppliers should bear full responsibility for their products, regardless of the underlying components. Allowing reduced liability for OSS would transfer significant risk to Zebracorp.
content.conditions: Applies to all agreements where suppliers incorporate OSS.
content.justification: Establishes a critical principle that supplier liability (warranties, indemnities) must not be diminished by the use of OSS.
content.implication_company: Right to full warranties and indemnities from the supplier, irrespective of OSS inclusion.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to provide full warranties and indemnities for products containing OSS, accepting full responsibility.
content.source_insight: Clearly states Zebracorp's strong position on supplier liability for OSS-containing products.
content.text: The supplier’s election to incorporate OSS components into its products should not limit the warranties and indemnities available to Zebracorp under the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Having the OSS license terms determine the indemnity and warranty terms is only acceptable if Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge, but it should be challenged if the OSS is sold or licensed to Zebracorp as part of a product or solution that has a price tag.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should only accept OSS license terms determining indemnity and warranty if the OSS code is obtained free of charge; otherwise, this should be challenged if the OSS is part of a paid product or solution.
content.expert_insight: This provides a clear negotiation strategy. If Zebracorp is paying for a product, it expects commercial-grade warranties and indemnities, not the 'as-is' terms typical of free OSS. This protects Zebracorp from paying for a product while receiving limited legal recourse.
content.conditions: Acceptable only if OSS is free; otherwise, it must be challenged if OSS is part of a paid product/solution.
content.justification: Provides a conditional acceptance rule for a critical commercial term (indemnity/warranty), directly impacting risk and cost.
content.implication_company: Right to challenge limited warranties/indemnities for paid OSS; obligation to accept 'as-is' terms for truly free OSS.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to provide commercial warranties/indemnities for paid products containing OSS; cannot rely on OSS license terms to limit liability.
content.source_insight: Offers a nuanced approach to indemnity and warranty terms based on whether the OSS is 'free' or 'paid-for'.
content.text: Having the OSS license terms determine the indemnity and warranty terms is only acceptable if Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge, but it should be challenged if the OSS is sold or licensed to Zebracorp as part of a product or solution that has a price tag.

content.verbatim_text: The supplier should not get the benefit of reduced liability as a result of using OSS in its products.
content.plain_text: The supplier must not benefit from reduced liability due to incorporating OSS into its products.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces the principle that the supplier, as the commercial vendor, must assume full responsibility for the entire product, including its OSS components. Any reduction in liability would unfairly transfer risk to Zebracorp.
content.conditions: Applies to all products supplied to Zebracorp that contain OSS.
content.justification: States a fundamental principle regarding supplier liability, which is a critical commercial term.
content.implication_company: Right to hold supplier fully liable for products containing OSS.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to accept full liability for products containing OSS, without seeking reduced responsibility.
content.source_insight: A clear statement of Zebracorp's policy on supplier liability for OSS.
content.text: The supplier should not get the benefit of reduced liability as a result of using OSS in its products.

content.verbatim_text: In order to give Zebracorp and its end customers the opportunity to review any restrictions contained in the license terms, the suppliers should at a minimum be required to provide details of any open source software included in any of the deliverables provided to us as well as details on the applicable license terms (which also include the respective version numbers of these license terms).
content.plain_text: Suppliers must, at a minimum, provide details of all OSS included in deliverables, along with applicable license terms and their version numbers, to allow Zebracorp and its end customers to review restrictions.
content.expert_insight: This is a foundational requirement for OSS governance. Without this information, Zebracorp cannot perform due diligence, ensure compliance, or manage the risks associated with OSS, potentially leading to legal exposure and inability to distribute products.
content.conditions: Applies to all deliverables provided to Zebracorp that include OSS.
content.justification: Mandates essential disclosure from suppliers, critical for Zebracorp's compliance, risk management, and ability to distribute products.
content.implication_company: Right to receive comprehensive OSS disclosure; ability to perform due diligence and ensure compliance.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to provide detailed and accurate information on all OSS components and their licenses.
content.source_insight: Highlights the importance of transparency for both Zebracorp and its end customers.
content.text: In order to give Zebracorp and its end customers the opportunity to review any restrictions contained in the license terms, the suppliers should at a minimum be required to provide details of any open source software included in any of the deliverables provided to us as well as details on the applicable license terms (which also include the respective version numbers of these license terms).

content.verbatim_text: Information on license terms is also important since the use and distribution of open source software often requires that the open source license is passed onwards to the end users of the software.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must pass on open source licenses to end users where required by the OSS license terms.
content.expert_insight: Many OSS licenses, especially copyleft ones, mandate that the license text and sometimes source code be provided to downstream recipients. Failure to do so constitutes a license violation, potentially leading to infringement claims.
content.conditions: Applies when OSS license terms require onward distribution to end users.
content.justification: Implies an obligation for Zebracorp to comply with a common OSS license requirement, crucial for legal distribution.
content.implication_company: Obligation to ensure proper distribution of OSS licenses to end users; risk of non-compliance if not done.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must provide the necessary license information to Zebracorp to enable this onward distribution.
content.source_insight: Provides a justification for the importance of license information, implicitly stating an obligation for Zebracorp.
content.text: Information on license terms is also important since the use and distribution of open source software often requires that the open source license is passed onwards to the end users of the software.

content.verbatim_text: Suppliers of OSS components should be able to also provide: (i) the entire open source software license text in editable text form; and (ii) for any open source software requiring redistribution as part of its license terms, necessary tools and information to build the source code.
content.plain_text: Suppliers of OSS components must provide: (i) the full OSS license text in editable format; and (ii) for OSS requiring redistribution, necessary tools and information to build the source code.
content.expert_insight: Editable license text is crucial for easy inclusion in Zebracorp's documentation. Providing build tools and information for redistributable OSS is essential for Zebracorp to comply with 'source code availability' requirements of many copyleft licenses, preventing legal breaches.
content.conditions: Applies to suppliers providing OSS components.
content.justification: Mandates specific deliverables from suppliers that are critical for Zebracorp's compliance and operational needs.
content.implication_company: Right to receive these specific items from suppliers, enabling compliance and transparency.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to provide license text in editable form and, for certain OSS, build tools/information.
content.source_insight: Details specific requirements for supplier deliverables beyond just listing OSS components.
content.text: Suppliers of OSS components should be able to also provide: (i) the entire open source software license text in editable text form; and (ii) for any open source software requiring redistribution as part of its license terms, necessary tools and information to build the source code.

content.verbatim_text: “The [Licensor] represents and warrants to [ZEBRACORP] that no open source software in whole or in part is incorporated into any part of the [Products], save for the open source software disclosed by [ZEBRACORP] and listed in Appendix X (Disclosure) of this [Agreement], unless such open source software has been disclosed in advance to [ZEBRACORP] and subsequently accepted by [ZEBRACORP]. Such disclosure shall include open source component and component version and license and license version for each open source component.”
content.plain_text: The Licensor (supplier) warrants that no undisclosed OSS is incorporated into products. Any OSS must be disclosed in advance, accepted by Zebracorp, and the disclosure must include component, version, license, and license version.
content.expert_insight: This is a robust warranty clause. It places the burden on the supplier to ensure no 'hidden' OSS is present and mandates a formal disclosure and acceptance process for any OSS, giving Zebracorp control and visibility over its supply chain's OSS usage.
content.conditions: Applies to all products supplied by the Licensor.
content.justification: This is a direct contractual warranty and obligation, critical for IP protection and risk management.
content.implication_company: Right to receive products free of undisclosed OSS; right to accept/reject disclosed OSS; protection via supplier warranty.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to warrant no undisclosed OSS; obligation to disclose and seek acceptance for any OSS, providing full details.
content.source_insight: Presented as an example disclosure clause, indicating a strong preferred contractual position.
content.text: “The [Licensor] represents and warrants to [ZEBRACORP] that no open source software in whole or in part is incorporated into any part of the [Products], save for the open source software disclosed by [ZEBRACORP] and listed in Appendix X (Disclosure) of this [Agreement], unless such open source software has been disclosed in advance to [ZEBRACORP] and subsequently accepted by [ZEBRACORP]. Such disclosure shall include open source component and component version and license and license version for each open source component.”

content.verbatim_text: The standard warranties and indemnities should apply to the OSS code, unless Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge.
content.plain_text: Standard warranties and indemnities must apply to OSS code, unless Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates Zebracorp's stance on supplier responsibility. If Zebracorp is paying for a product, it expects full commercial protections, regardless of the components. The 'free of charge' exception acknowledges the nature of truly free OSS.
content.conditions: Applies unless Zebracorp obtains OSS code free of charge.
content.justification: Reaffirms a critical commercial term (warranties/indemnities) and its conditional application to OSS.
content.implication_company: Right to standard warranties/indemnities for OSS in paid products; acknowledges 'as-is' for free OSS.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to provide standard warranties/indemnities for OSS in paid products.
content.source_insight: A concise restatement of a key principle regarding liability for OSS.
content.text: The standard warranties and indemnities should apply to the OSS code, unless Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge.

content.verbatim_text: We can accept that OSS code is subject to respective OSS license terms, but the supplier should ensure that those license terms are consistent with the licenses that the supplier has granted to Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp accepts that OSS code is subject to its own license terms, but the supplier must ensure these terms are consistent with the licenses granted by the supplier to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This balances the reality of OSS licensing with Zebracorp's need for clear, consistent rights. The supplier is responsible for ensuring that their choice of OSS does not create conflicts that undermine the commercial agreement with Zebracorp.
content.conditions: Applies when OSS code is incorporated into products supplied to Zebracorp.
content.justification: Sets a clear expectation for supplier responsibility regarding license consistency, mitigating potential conflicts.
content.implication_company: Accepts OSS license terms but expects consistency with supplier grants; protection against conflicting rights.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to ensure consistency between OSS license terms and licenses granted to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Provides a balanced approach to accepting OSS license terms while protecting Zebracorp's rights.
content.text: We can accept that OSS code is subject to respective OSS license terms, but the supplier should ensure that those license terms are consistent with the licenses that the supplier has granted to Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Should there be any unresolved conflict between any term or condition contained in this [Agreement] and any terms or conditions of any such open source license(s), the terms and conditions of the applicable open source license(s) shall supersede the license grant or restrictions herein. However, nothing in the open source software license shall limit or restrict [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under this Agreement, or the [Licensor]’s obligations including but not limited to any warranties or indemnity obligations under this [Agreement]. For clarification, nothing in this [Agreement] shall further be construed to limit [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under the applicable open source license terms.
content.plain_text: In case of conflict, OSS license terms supersede the main agreement's license grant/restrictions. However, OSS licenses must not limit Zebracorp's rights or the Licensor's obligations (including warranties/indemnities) under the main agreement. The main agreement also does not limit Zebracorp's rights under OSS licenses.
content.expert_insight: This is a sophisticated conflict resolution clause. It acknowledges OSS license precedence for *license grants* but critically carves out Zebracorp's broader contractual rights and supplier obligations (especially warranties and indemnities), ensuring Zebracorp is protected. It also ensures Zebracorp retains any rights granted by the OSS license itself.
content.conditions: Applies in cases of unresolved conflict between the main agreement and OSS license terms.
content.justification: This is a comprehensive and critical clause for managing conflicts, protecting Zebracorp's core rights and supplier obligations.
content.implication_company: Rights under the main agreement (including warranties/indemnities) are preserved; rights under OSS licenses are also preserved; clear conflict resolution mechanism.
content.implication_supplier: Obligations (including warranties/indemnities) under the main agreement are preserved, even if OSS license terms conflict; must ensure OSS licenses do not limit these.
content.source_insight: Presented as an example provision, indicating a highly preferred and robust contractual clause.
content.text: Should there be any unresolved conflict between any term or condition contained in this [Agreement] and any terms or conditions of any such open source license(s), the terms and conditions of the applicable open source license(s) shall supersede the license grant or restrictions herein. However, nothing in the open source software license shall limit or restrict [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under this Agreement, or the [Licensor]’s obligations including but not limited to any warranties or indemnity obligations under this [Agreement]. For clarification, nothing in this [Agreement] shall further be construed to limit [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under the applicable open source license terms.

content.verbatim_text: The vendor of a commercial product should accept responsibility for the entire product even if it contains OSS code.
content.plain_text: The vendor of a commercial product must accept responsibility for the entire product, including any OSS code it contains.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental principle for commercial transactions. Zebracorp is buying a complete solution, not individual components. The vendor must stand behind their entire offering, regardless of its internal composition.
content.conditions: Applies to vendors supplying commercial products containing OSS.
content.justification: States a core principle of supplier responsibility for the entire product, which is a high-impact commercial term.
content.implication_company: Right to hold vendor responsible for the entire product, including OSS components.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to accept full responsibility for the entire product, even if it contains OSS.
content.source_insight: Presented as an argument in support of Zebracorp's position, indicating a desired contractual obligation.
content.text: The vendor of a commercial product should accept responsibility for the entire product even if it contains OSS code.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp performs checks on all OSS components and requires details on these components in order to complete the checks.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp requires suppliers to provide details on all OSS components to enable Zebracorp to perform necessary checks.
content.expert_insight: This highlights Zebracorp's internal due diligence process and creates a corresponding obligation for suppliers to provide the necessary information. It's crucial for risk assessment and compliance verification.
content.conditions: Applies to all OSS components supplied to Zebracorp.
content.justification: States an internal Zebracorp process that necessitates a supplier obligation, critical for risk management.
content.implication_company: Obligation to perform checks on OSS components; right to demand necessary details from suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to provide details on OSS components to facilitate Zebracorp's checks.
content.source_insight: Explains Zebracorp's internal process and its implication for supplier requirements.
content.text: Zebracorp performs checks on all OSS components and requires details on these components in order to complete the checks.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp needs detailed information on the OSS components and the applicable license terms in order to be able to comply with those terms and, where required, to distribute these onwards to its customers.
content.plain_text: Suppliers must provide detailed information on OSS components and their applicable license terms to enable Zebracorp to comply with terms and distribute them to customers.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical information requirement. Without detailed information, Zebracorp cannot ensure its own compliance with OSS licenses, nor can it fulfill its obligations to pass on licenses to its customers, leading to potential legal breaches and operational failures.
content.conditions: Applies to all OSS components supplied to Zebracorp.
content.justification: Directly links the need for information to Zebracorp's ability to comply with legal obligations and distribute products, making it critical.
content.implication_company: Obligation to comply with OSS terms and distribute them; right to receive detailed information from suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to provide detailed information on OSS components and license terms.
content.source_insight: Provides a strong justification for the supplier's disclosure obligation, emphasizing the risks of non-compliance.
content.text: Zebracorp needs detailed information on the OSS components and the applicable license terms in order to be able to comply with those terms and, where required, to distribute these onwards to its customers.

content.verbatim_text: “To the knowledge of the [Supplier], no proprietary intellectual property is, in whole or in part, subject to the provision of any open source or other type of license agreement or distribution model that: requires the distribution or making available of the source code for any proprietary intellectual property, prohibits or limits [Party] from charging a fee or receiving consideration in connection with sublicensing or distributing any proprietary intellectual property, grants any right to or otherwise allows anyone to decompile, disassemble or otherwise reverse-engineer any proprietary intellectual property, or requires the licensing of any proprietary intellectual property for the purpose of making derivative works.”
content.plain_text: The Supplier warrants that, to its knowledge, no proprietary IP is subject to OSS licenses that: require source code distribution, prohibit charging fees for sublicensing/distribution, allow decompilation/reverse-engineering, or require licensing for derivative works.
content.expert_insight: This is a powerful warranty designed to protect Zebracorp's proprietary IP from 'viral' effects or other restrictive OSS terms. It ensures that the supplier has vetted their own IP for OSS contamination that could compromise Zebracorp's commercial interests.
content.conditions: Applies to proprietary intellectual property supplied by the Supplier.
content.justification: This is a direct contractual covenant protecting Zebracorp's core proprietary IP from critical OSS license restrictions.
content.implication_company: Protection of proprietary IP from viral OSS effects; right to rely on supplier's warranty.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to warrant the absence of specific restrictive OSS license provisions affecting proprietary IP; due diligence required.
content.source_insight: Presented as a covenant example, detailing specific prohibitions against problematic OSS license types.
content.text: “To the knowledge of the [Supplier], no proprietary intellectual property is, in whole or in part, subject to the provision of any open source or other type of license agreement or distribution model that: requires the distribution or making available of the source code for any proprietary intellectual property, prohibits or limits [Party] from charging a fee or receiving consideration in connection with sublicensing or distributing any proprietary intellectual property, grants any right to or otherwise allows anyone to decompile, disassemble or otherwise reverse-engineer any proprietary intellectual property, or requires the licensing of any proprietary intellectual property for the purpose of making derivative works.”

content.verbatim_text: Note that above covenants should always be required in those cases where the supplier is for whatever reason unable to provide the details of the OSS components and the applicable license terms.
content.plain_text: The aforementioned covenants (regarding proprietary IP not being subject to restrictive OSS licenses) must always be required if the supplier cannot provide details of OSS components and their license terms.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a critical fallback position. If a supplier cannot provide transparency on OSS, Zebracorp must demand strong warranties to mitigate the unknown risks. This is a crucial risk management strategy when full disclosure is not possible.
content.conditions: Applies when the supplier is unable to provide details of OSS components and applicable license terms.
content.justification: Mandates a critical risk mitigation strategy when primary disclosure requirements cannot be met, protecting Zebracorp from unknown risks.
content.implication_company: Right to demand strong covenants as a fallback; protection against undisclosed OSS risks.
content.implication_supplier: Obligation to provide these covenants if unable to provide full OSS disclosure.
content.source_insight: Provides a specific condition under which the preceding strong covenants become mandatory.
content.text: Note that above covenants should always be required in those cases where the supplier is for whatever reason unable to provide the details of the OSS components and the applicable license terms.

content.verbatim_text: Open source software (OSS) and free software generally refer to software, which is free from any onerous licensing restrictions, and which is available for any person to view, edit, and/or change code.
content.plain_text: Open source software (OSS) is defined as software free from onerous licensing restrictions, allowing anyone to view, edit, and change its code.
content.expert_insight: This provides a foundational understanding of OSS, emphasizing its core characteristics of accessibility and modifiability, which are key to its legal and practical implications.
content.justification: Provides a general definition of open source software.
content.implication_company: Helps Zebracorp understand the basic nature and intent behind OSS.
content.implication_supplier: Standard definition of OSS that suppliers should also adhere to.
content.source_insight: Basic, widely accepted definition of OSS.
content.text: Open source software (OSS) and free software generally refer to software, which is free from any onerous licensing restrictions, and which is available for any person to view, edit, and/or change code.

content.verbatim_text: A common misunderstanding is to assume that open source code is public domain and free for anyone to use. However, open source code is, in fact, copyrighted and relies heavily to copyright protection. As with any other copyrighted work (such as in e.g. Microsoft’s Office Pack), you need a license from the copyright holder to use the code.
content.plain_text: Contrary to common belief, open source code is copyrighted, not public domain, and requires a license from the copyright holder for its use, similar to proprietary software.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical clarification, dispelling a common misconception that could lead to legal non-compliance. It underscores that even 'free' software operates under a legal framework requiring adherence to specific licenses.
content.justification: Corrects a common misunderstanding about the legal status of OSS and emphasizes the need for licensing.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must recognize that OSS is copyrighted and requires strict license compliance, not free-for-all use.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must also respect OSS copyright and ensure proper licensing for any OSS components they use or provide.
content.source_insight: Highlights the legal framework and common pitfalls regarding OSS.
content.text: A common misunderstanding is to assume that open source code is public domain and free for anyone to use. However, open source code is, in fact, copyrighted and relies heavily to copyright protection. As with any other copyrighted work (such as in e.g. Microsoft’s Office Pack), you need a license from the copyright holder to use the code.

content.verbatim_text: It is good to keep in mind that only by being in compliance with the OSS license terms, we have rights to use the copyrighted OSS software.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's right to use copyrighted OSS is strictly conditional on compliance with its specific license terms.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental instruction for Zebracorp, emphasizing that legal use of OSS is not automatic but contingent upon strict adherence to its license. It's a core principle for risk management.
content.justification: States a critical requirement for the legal use of OSS.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must prioritize and ensure strict compliance with all OSS license terms to maintain legal usage rights and avoid infringement.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must provide clear and accurate OSS license terms to enable Zebracorp's compliance.
content.source_insight: A core legal principle for OSS usage.
content.text: It is good to keep in mind that only by being in compliance with the OSS license terms, we have rights to use the copyrighted OSS software.

content.verbatim_text: Most open source software licenses grant licensees somewhat free right to copy, modify and redistribute source code. However, these licenses may also impose obligations such as for example a requirement that modifications to the code that are distributed must be made available in source code form, requirement to include copyright notices, requirements on how software can be redistributed, or requirement to freely release the combined software code (incorporating the open source code).
content.plain_text: While OSS licenses generally permit copying, modification, and redistribution, they often impose obligations such as making modifications available in source code form, including copyright notices, or requiring the free release of combined software.
content.expert_insight: This explains the dual nature of OSS licenses: granting freedoms while simultaneously imposing specific obligations. Zebracorp must be aware of these potential requirements, especially concerning distribution and source code availability, to avoid non-compliance.
content.justification: Explains common obligations and restrictions found in OSS licenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to be aware of and prepared to fulfill these obligations if it modifies or distributes OSS, to avoid legal issues.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must ensure Zebracorp is fully aware of these obligations for any OSS they provide.
content.source_insight: Provides examples of common OSS license restrictions and requirements.
content.text: Most open source software licenses grant licensees somewhat free right to copy, modify and redistribute source code. However, these licenses may also impose obligations such as for example a requirement that modifications to the code that are distributed must be made available in source code form, requirement to include copyright notices, requirements on how software can be redistributed, or requirement to freely release the combined software code (incorporating the open source code).

content.verbatim_text: Open source software that imposes requirements on distribution are generally known as ‘strong open source license’ or so called ‘copyleft’ open source license. A typical example of such copyleft or strong OSS is GNU General Public License (GPL), which is perhaps the most widely used open source software. Under the GPL license, the derived works can only be distributed under the same license terms.
content.plain_text: Licenses imposing distribution requirements are called 'strong open source' or 'copyleft' licenses, like the GNU General Public License (GPL), which mandates that derived works must be distributed under the same license terms.
content.expert_insight: This introduces the critical concept of 'copyleft' and its 'viral' nature, particularly with GPL. Zebracorp must understand these licenses to identify and manage the significant risks associated with their restrictive terms on derived works.
content.justification: Defines and provides an example of 'copyleft' licenses and their core requirement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must exercise extreme caution with copyleft licenses like GPL due to their potential to impose their terms on derivative works.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must clearly identify and explain the implications of using copyleft licenses in their products.
content.source_insight: Highlights the most common and impactful copyleft license (GPL).
content.text: Open source software that imposes requirements on distribution are generally known as ‘strong open source license’ or so called ‘copyleft’ open source license. A typical example of such copyleft or strong OSS is GNU General Public License (GPL), which is perhaps the most widely used open source software. Under the GPL license, the derived works can only be distributed under the same license terms.

content.verbatim_text: In some instances Zebracorp proprietary software can be ‘contaminated’ with open source code. This contamination occurs when software created from open source code or containing open source code must be made freely available according to the terms of the original open source license. This so called viral effect means that if a piece of in e.g. GPL code is used in a work that includes proprietary code, then this resulting work must become open under the GPL in its entirety. In an extreme case scenario a minor piece of open source code contaminates an entire software bundle rendering it legally impossible to hide its source code.
content.plain_text: Proprietary software can be 'contaminated' by copyleft OSS (e.g., GPL), leading to a 'viral effect' where the entire combined work must become open source, potentially exposing Zebracorp's proprietary code.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical risk explanation for Zebracorp. Understanding the 'viral effect' is paramount for protecting its proprietary intellectual property when integrating OSS, as even minor inclusions can have significant, unintended consequences.
content.justification: Explains the significant risk of 'viral effect' from strong OSS licenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must implement strict controls and reviews to prevent proprietary code contamination by viral OSS licenses.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must guarantee that their use of OSS does not lead to contamination of Zebracorp's proprietary software.
content.source_insight: Clearly articulates the most severe consequence of copyleft licenses.
content.text: In some instances Zebracorp proprietary software can be ‘contaminated’ with open source code. This contamination occurs when software created from open source code or containing open source code must be made freely available according to the terms of the original open source license. This so called viral effect means that if a piece of in e.g. GPL code is used in a work that includes proprietary code, then this resulting work must become open under the GPL in its entirety. In an extreme case scenario a minor piece of open source code contaminates an entire software bundle rendering it legally impossible to hide its source code.

content.verbatim_text: Generally speaking open source software that has reciprocity or share-alike requirements (i.e. that require all distributed copies or/and modified versions of a work to be free of charge or freely available to be modified), are problematic. This is in contrast to so called ‘permissive open source software’ or ‘flexible open source license’ in e.g. Apache which has minimal requirements on how the software can be redistributed and which usually permit the re-distributor to combine the licensed material with other license terms, potentially adding further restrictions to a derived work.
content.plain_text: OSS with 'reciprocity' or 'share-alike' requirements (mandating free distribution/modification) are problematic, unlike 'permissive' licenses (e.g., Apache) which have minimal restrictions and allow combining with other license terms.
content.expert_insight: This provides a clear distinction between problematic (copyleft/share-alike) and preferred (permissive) OSS licenses. Zebracorp should strategically favor permissive licenses to maintain flexibility and protect its IP.
content.justification: Differentiates between problematic (copyleft) and less problematic (permissive) OSS licenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should strategically favor permissive OSS licenses (like Apache) and be highly cautious of share-alike licenses.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should ideally use permissive OSS licenses or clearly flag problematic ones to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Offers a strategic preference for certain license types based on their impact.
content.text: Generally speaking open source software that has reciprocity or share-alike requirements (i.e. that require all distributed copies or/and modified versions of a work to be free of charge or freely available to be modified), are problematic. This is in contrast to so called ‘permissive open source software’ or ‘flexible open source license’ in e.g. Apache which has minimal requirements on how the software can be redistributed and which usually permit the re-distributor to combine the licensed material with other license terms, potentially adding further restrictions to a derived work.

content.verbatim_text: Because of the nature of OSS, any modifications to the any OSS code must be considered carefully by Zebracorp IPR. Modifications to the GPL code are generally not possible.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's IPR department must carefully review any modifications to OSS code, noting that modifications to GPL code are generally not feasible.
content.expert_insight: This is a direct instruction for internal process and a strong warning about the extreme inflexibility of GPL. It highlights the necessity of expert legal review before any modification attempts to OSS, especially GPL.
content.justification: Mandates careful IPR review for OSS modifications and highlights a specific restriction for GPL.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's IPR department must be involved in all OSS modification decisions, particularly concerning GPL, to avoid legal pitfalls.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware of Zebracorp's internal IPR review process for OSS modifications.
content.source_insight: Emphasizes the legal complexity of modifying OSS, particularly GPL.
content.text: Because of the nature of OSS, any modifications to the any OSS code must be considered carefully by Zebracorp IPR. Modifications to the GPL code are generally not possible.

content.verbatim_text: We can usually agree that the terms and conditions of the license grant of the applicable open source software license will take precedence over the license grant of our mutual agreement. In that case, we should specifically state that nothing contained in those open source license terms will restrict the rights granted to Zebracorp under the agreement.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can agree to OSS license terms taking precedence over the license grant in the main agreement, but must explicitly state that OSS terms do not restrict Zebracorp's rights granted under the main agreement.
content.expert_insight: This is a key negotiation tactic. It acknowledges the reality of OSS license precedence for the license grant itself, but provides a crucial safeguard to protect Zebracorp's broader contractual rights, preventing unintended erosion of the commercial agreement.
content.justification: Provides a negotiation strategy for handling conflicting OSS license terms.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept OSS license precedence for the grant, but must ensure its core rights under the main agreement are preserved.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be prepared to agree that OSS terms will not diminish Zebracorp's rights in the main contract.
content.source_insight: Offers a practical approach to managing license conflicts while protecting core rights.
content.text: We can usually agree that the terms and conditions of the license grant of the applicable open source software license will take precedence over the license grant of our mutual agreement. In that case, we should specifically state that nothing contained in those open source license terms will restrict the rights granted to Zebracorp under the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: So while we accept the license restrictions that come with the OSS, the supplier of the code should make sure that those restrictions do not conflict with the licenses and rights that it has granted to Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: While Zebracorp accepts inherent OSS license restrictions, the supplier is responsible for ensuring these restrictions do not conflict with the rights the supplier has granted to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical allocation of responsibility. Zebracorp accepts the 'as-is' nature of OSS restrictions, but the *supplier* bears the burden of ensuring compatibility with their own contractual grants, effectively shifting the risk of conflict to them.
content.justification: Defines the supplier's responsibility regarding OSS license compatibility with their grants to Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can rely on the supplier to manage conflicts between OSS licenses and the supplier's own grants, reducing Zebracorp's burden.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier is responsible for ensuring that OSS license terms do not undermine the rights they grant to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Clearly assigns responsibility for license compatibility.
content.text: So while we accept the license restrictions that come with the OSS, the supplier of the code should make sure that those restrictions do not conflict with the licenses and rights that it has granted to Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: As for all terms and conditions other than license terms, our position should be that the terms of our mutual agreement will apply also to the OSS components of a particular product. This means that in e.g. the IPR indemnity that protects us against third party infringement claims applies also the OSS components.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's position is that all non-license terms (e.g., IPR indemnity) of the mutual agreement should apply to OSS components, ensuring protection against third-party infringement claims.
content.expert_insight: This is a strong negotiation position. It ensures that critical protections like indemnities, which are typically absent in OSS licenses, are extended to OSS components via the commercial agreement with the supplier. This is vital for comprehensive risk mitigation.
content.justification: States Zebracorp's position that general contractual terms (like indemnities) should apply to OSS components.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp seeks to extend the full protection of its commercial agreement, including indemnities, to all OSS components, regardless of their origin.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must accept that their general contractual obligations, such as IPR indemnities, will cover OSS components they provide.
content.source_insight: Provides a specific example (IPR indemnity) to illustrate the point.
content.text: As for all terms and conditions other than license terms, our position should be that the terms of our mutual agreement will apply also to the OSS components of a particular product. This means that in e.g. the IPR indemnity that protects us against third party infringement claims applies also the OSS components.

content.verbatim_text: The supplier’s election to incorporate OSS components into its products should not limit the warranties and indemnities available to Zebracorp under the agreement.
content.plain_text: The supplier's choice to use OSS components in its products should not diminish the warranties and indemnities Zebracorp receives under the main agreement.
content.expert_insight: This is a direct and firm negotiation stance. It prevents suppliers from using OSS as an excuse to dilute their liability or warranty obligations, ensuring Zebracorp receives consistent protection regardless of the underlying code's origin.
content.justification: Reinforces that a supplier's use of OSS should not diminish their contractual obligations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp expects full warranty and indemnity protection, irrespective of OSS inclusion in a product.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers cannot use OSS as a reason to limit their liability or warranties to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: A clear statement of Zebracorp's non-negotiable position on supplier liability.
content.text: The supplier’s election to incorporate OSS components into its products should not limit the warranties and indemnities available to Zebracorp under the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: The license terms of the OSS generally do not provide any protection against third party IPR infringement claims. Having the OSS license terms determine the indemnity and warranty terms is only acceptable if Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge, but it should be challenged if the OSS is sold or licensed to Zebracorp as part of a product or solution that has a price tag. The supplier should not get the benefit of reduced liability as a result of using OSS in its products.
content.plain_text: OSS licenses typically lack IPR infringement protection. Zebracorp should only accept OSS license terms governing indemnity/warranty if the OSS is free; otherwise, it must challenge this, ensuring the supplier doesn't benefit from reduced liability when selling products containing OSS.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial tactical instruction. It highlights a common gap in OSS licenses (lack of IPR indemnity) and provides a clear strategy for negotiation based on whether the OSS is part of a paid solution. It aims to prevent suppliers from externalizing risk onto Zebracorp.
content.justification: Explains the lack of IPR protection in OSS licenses and provides a negotiation strategy based on whether the OSS is part of a paid product.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must actively negotiate for IPR indemnity and warranties for OSS components in paid products, refusing reduced supplier liability.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers cannot expect reduced liability for OSS components if they are part of a commercial product sold to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Provides a strong rationale for Zebracorp's negotiation position on liability.
content.text: The license terms of the OSS generally do not provide any protection against third party IPR infringement claims. Having the OSS license terms determine the indemnity and warranty terms is only acceptable if Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge, but it should be challenged if the OSS is sold or licensed to Zebracorp as part of a product or solution that has a price tag. The supplier should not get the benefit of reduced liability as a result of using OSS in its products.

content.verbatim_text: In order to give Zebracorp and its end customers the opportunity to review any restrictions contained in the license terms, the suppliers should at a minimum be required to provide details of any open source software included in any of the deliverables provided to us as well as details on the applicable license terms (which also include the respective version numbers of these license terms).
content.plain_text: Suppliers must provide details of all included OSS and their license terms (including version numbers) to allow Zebracorp and its end customers to review restrictions.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental instruction for due diligence and transparency. Requiring detailed disclosure is essential for Zebracorp to assess risks, ensure compliance, and manage its own obligations to end customers.
content.justification: Mandates supplier disclosure of OSS details for Zebracorp's review and compliance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs this information to perform its own risk assessment, ensure compliance, and fulfill downstream obligations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are obligated to provide comprehensive details about all OSS components and their licenses.
content.source_insight: Underpins Zebracorp's ability to manage OSS risks effectively.
content.text: In order to give Zebracorp and its end customers the opportunity to review any restrictions contained in the license terms, the suppliers should at a minimum be required to provide details of any open source software included in any of the deliverables provided to us as well as details on the applicable license terms (which also include the respective version numbers of these license terms).

content.verbatim_text: Information on license terms is also important since the use and distribution of open source software often requires that the open source license is passed onwards to the end users of the software.
content.plain_text: Information on OSS license terms is crucial because many licenses require them to be passed on to end-users.
content.expert_insight: This provides a clear justification for the disclosure requirement, linking it directly to Zebracorp's downstream compliance obligations. It highlights a practical aspect of OSS management.
content.justification: Explains why detailed OSS license information is critical for Zebracorp's downstream compliance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must be prepared to pass on OSS license terms to its end-users, necessitating accurate information from suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand that their disclosure obligations help Zebracorp fulfill its own distribution requirements.
content.source_insight: Highlights a common compliance requirement for OSS distribution.
content.text: Information on license terms is also important since the use and distribution of open source software often requires that the open source license is passed onwards to the end users of the software.

content.verbatim_text: Suppliers of OSS components should be able to also provide: (i) the entire open source software license text in editable text form; and (ii) for any open source software requiring redistribution as part of its license terms, necessary tools and information to build the source code.
content.plain_text: Suppliers should provide the full OSS license text in editable format and, for redistributable OSS, the tools and information needed to build the source code.
content.expert_insight: These are specific, actionable requirements for suppliers, going beyond mere disclosure to enable Zebracorp's full compliance and operational needs, especially for managing copyleft licenses.
content.justification: Specifies additional requirements for suppliers to facilitate Zebracorp's compliance and use of OSS.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs these resources to ensure full compliance and, if necessary, to fulfill redistribution obligations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be prepared to provide these specific resources to Zebracorp as part of their contractual obligations.
content.source_insight: Details practical requirements for managing OSS, particularly for compliance and build processes.
content.text: Suppliers of OSS components should be able to also provide: (i) the entire open source software license text in editable text form; and (ii) for any open source software requiring redistribution as part of its license terms, necessary tools and information to build the source code.

content.verbatim_text: Below is an example of disclosure clause: “The [Licensor] represents and warrants to [ZEBRACORP] that no open source software in whole or in part is incorporated into any part of the [Products], save for the open source software disclosed by [ZEBRACORP] and listed in Appendix X (Disclosure) of this [Agreement], unless such open source software has been disclosed in advance to [ZEBRACORP] and subsequently accepted by [ZEBRACORP]. Such disclosure shall include open source component and component version and license and license version for each open source component.”
content.plain_text: An example contractual clause requires the licensor to warrant that no undisclosed OSS is incorporated, and that all disclosed OSS (listed in an appendix or pre-approved) includes component, version, and license details.
content.expert_insight: This is a concrete example of how to implement the disclosure requirements contractually. It provides a template for Zebracorp's legal team to use in agreements, ensuring a clear contractual obligation for the supplier regarding OSS transparency.
content.justification: Illustrates a contractual clause for OSS disclosure.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this clause to enforce supplier disclosure and acceptance of OSS components, enhancing control and reducing risk.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will be contractually bound by such a clause to disclose and warrant their OSS usage, requiring internal tracking.
content.source_insight: A practical legal drafting example for OSS disclosure.
content.text: Below is an example of disclosure clause: “The [Licensor] represents and warrants to [ZEBRACORP] that no open source software in whole or in part is incorporated into any part of the [Products], save for the open source software disclosed by [ZEBRACORP] and listed in Appendix X (Disclosure) of this [Agreement], unless such open source software has been disclosed in advance to [ZEBRACORP] and subsequently accepted by [ZEBRACORP]. Such disclosure shall include open source component and component version and license and license version for each open source component.”

content.verbatim_text: The standard warranties and indemnities should apply to the OSS code, unless Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge. We can accept that OSS code is subject to respective OSS license terms, but the supplier should ensure that those license terms are consistent with the licenses that the supplier has granted to Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Standard warranties and indemnities should cover OSS code unless it's free. Zebracorp accepts OSS license terms but requires the supplier to ensure consistency with rights granted by the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates and consolidates previous tactical points regarding warranties, indemnities, and license consistency. It's a strong summary of Zebracorp's core negotiation position on these critical aspects, emphasizing supplier responsibility.
content.justification: Reaffirms Zebracorp's position on applying standard warranties/indemnities to OSS and ensuring license consistency.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains its demand for comprehensive protection and consistent rights, reducing its exposure to OSS-related risks.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are reminded of their obligation to provide consistent rights and warranties for OSS components, especially in paid products.
content.source_insight: Consolidates key negotiation points for OSS in commercial agreements.
content.text: The standard warranties and indemnities should apply to the OSS code, unless Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge. We can accept that OSS code is subject to respective OSS license terms, but the supplier should ensure that those license terms are consistent with the licenses that the supplier has granted to Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: See an example provision below. “The open source software is subject to the license terms of the open source license. Should there be any unresolved conflict between any term or condition contained in this [Agreement] and any terms or conditions of any such open source license(s), the terms and conditions of the applicable open source license(s) shall supersede the license grant or restrictions herein. However, nothing in the open source software license shall limit or restrict [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under this Agreement, or the [Licensor]’s obligations including but not limited to any warranties or indemnity obligations under this [Agreement]. For clarification, nothing in this [Agreement] shall further be construed to limit [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under the applicable open source license terms.”
content.plain_text: An example clause states that while OSS license terms supersede conflicting license grants in the main agreement, they do not limit Zebracorp's rights or the licensor's obligations (e.g., warranties, indemnities) under the main agreement.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial example of a contractual provision that operationalizes Zebracorp's negotiation tactic. It accepts OSS license precedence for *license grants* but safeguards all *other* rights and obligations (like warranties and indemnities) from the main agreement, a sophisticated legal drafting technique.
content.justification: Illustrates a contractual clause for managing conflicts between OSS licenses and the main agreement, protecting Zebracorp's rights.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this clause to protect its rights and supplier obligations in agreements involving OSS, ensuring comprehensive coverage.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will need to accept such a clause, ensuring their obligations to Zebracorp are not diminished by OSS licenses.
content.source_insight: A detailed legal drafting example for conflict resolution and rights protection.
content.text: See an example provision below. “The open source software is subject to the license terms of the open source license. Should there be any unresolved conflict between any term or condition contained in this [Agreement] and any terms or conditions of any such open source license(s), the terms and conditions of the applicable open source license(s) shall supersede the license grant or restrictions herein. However, nothing in the open source software license shall limit or restrict [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under this Agreement, or the [Licensor]’s obligations including but not limited to any warranties or indemnity obligations under this [Agreement]. For clarification, nothing in this [Agreement] shall further be construed to limit [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under the applicable open source license terms.”

content.verbatim_text: The vendor of a commercial product should accept responsibility for the entire product even if it contains OSS code.
content.plain_text: The vendor of a commercial product should accept full responsibility for the entire product, including any OSS code it contains.
content.expert_insight: This is a core argument for Zebracorp's negotiation position, emphasizing that the commercial nature of the product implies holistic vendor responsibility, regardless of component origin. It's a strong leverage point.
content.justification: Provides a key argument to use in negotiations with suppliers.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this argument to push for comprehensive supplier responsibility, simplifying risk management.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect this argument and be prepared to accept full responsibility for products containing OSS.
content.source_insight: A foundational principle for Zebracorp's stance on supplier accountability.
content.text: The vendor of a commercial product should accept responsibility for the entire product even if it contains OSS code.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp performs checks on all OSS components and requires details on these components in order to complete the checks.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp conducts internal checks on all OSS components and requires detailed information from suppliers to facilitate these checks.
content.expert_insight: This serves as both an internal instruction (perform checks) and a justification/leverage point for demanding information from suppliers. It implies a robust internal process for managing OSS risk.
content.justification: Explains Zebracorp's internal process and the reason for demanding OSS details.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must maintain its internal OSS review process to ensure compliance and mitigate risks.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp has an internal review process that necessitates detailed OSS information.
content.source_insight: Provides context for Zebracorp's information demands from suppliers.
content.text: Zebracorp performs checks on all OSS components and requires details on these components in order to complete the checks.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp needs detailed information on the OSS components and the applicable license terms in order to be able to comply with those terms and, where required, to distribute these onwards to its customers.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp requires detailed OSS component and license information to ensure its own compliance and to fulfill onward distribution requirements to customers.
content.expert_insight: This is another strong justification for demanding comprehensive OSS information, directly linking it to Zebracorp's legal and operational compliance needs, including downstream obligations to its own customers.
content.justification: Explains the necessity of detailed OSS information for Zebracorp's compliance and distribution obligations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp relies on accurate supplier information to meet its legal and customer obligations, making this information critical.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' disclosure directly impacts Zebracorp's ability to comply with OSS licenses and distribute products legally.
content.source_insight: Reinforces the importance of supplier transparency for Zebracorp's operations.
content.text: Zebracorp needs detailed information on the OSS components and the applicable license terms in order to be able to comply with those terms and, where required, to distribute these onwards to its customers.

content.verbatim_text: Having no information on the applicable open source software license terms may leave Zebracorp exposed to copyright infringement, injunction/sales ban, suits and/or loss of control over Zebracorp’s own proprietary code.
content.plain_text: Lack of information on OSS license terms exposes Zebracorp to significant risks, including copyright infringement, sales bans, lawsuits, and loss of control over its proprietary code.
content.expert_insight: This is a powerful statement of the risks involved, serving as a strong internal warning and a compelling argument to use with suppliers to justify stringent disclosure requirements. It highlights the severe business impact of non-compliance.
content.justification: Highlights the severe risks associated with insufficient OSS license information.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must prioritize obtaining complete OSS information to mitigate significant legal and business risks.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand the severe consequences for Zebracorp if they fail to provide adequate OSS information.
content.source_insight: Clearly articulates the negative consequences of non-compliance and lack of transparency.
content.text: Having no information on the applicable open source software license terms may leave Zebracorp exposed to copyright infringement, injunction/sales ban, suits and/or loss of control over Zebracorp’s own proprietary code.

content.verbatim_text: Depending on the circumstances we may require the following or substantially similar covenants from the supplier: “To the knowledge of the [Supplier], no proprietary intellectual property is, in whole or in part, subject to the provision of any open source or other type of license agreement or distribution model that: requires the distribution or making available of the source code for any proprietary intellectual property, prohibits or limits [Party] from charging a fee or receiving consideration in connection with sublicensing or distributing any proprietary intellectual property, grants any right to or otherwise allows anyone to decompile, disassemble or otherwise reverse-engineer any proprietary intellectual property, or requires the licensing of any proprietary intellectual property for the purpose of making derivative works.”
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may require covenants from suppliers warranting that their proprietary IP is not subject to OSS licenses that demand source code distribution, prohibit charging fees, allow reverse engineering, or require licensing for derivative works.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial set of protective covenants designed to prevent 'viral' effects and protect Zebracorp's proprietary IP. It's a strong contractual safeguard against unintended open-sourcing or loss of commercial control over valuable assets.
content.justification: Provides specific contractual covenants to protect Zebracorp's proprietary IP from problematic OSS license effects.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use these covenants to contractually protect its proprietary software from contamination and maintain control over its commercial terms.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be able to warrant that their proprietary IP is free from these specific OSS-related restrictions, requiring careful internal review.
content.source_insight: A detailed example of protective contractual language to mitigate specific OSS risks.

content.verbatim_text: In order to give Zebracorp and its end customers the opportunity to review any restrictions contained in the license terms, the suppliers should at a minimum be required to provide details of any open source software included in any of the deliverables provided to us as well as details on the applicable license terms (which also include the respective version numbers of these license terms).
content.plain_text: Suppliers must, at a minimum, provide details of all open source software included in deliverables, along with applicable license terms and version numbers, to allow Zebracorp and its customers to review restrictions.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical requirement for transparency and risk management. Without this information, Zebracorp cannot assess compliance or potential IP contamination.
content.justification: Enables Zebracorp and its customers to understand and comply with OSS license restrictions.
content.implication_company: Allows Zebracorp to perform due diligence, manage compliance, and mitigate risks.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier has a clear obligation to disclose OSS components and their license details.

content.verbatim_text: Information on license terms is also important since the use and distribution of open source software often requires that the open source license is passed onwards to the end users of the software.
content.plain_text: License term information is crucial because using and distributing open source software often requires passing the license to end users.
content.expert_insight: This provides a key justification for the disclosure requirement, highlighting the downstream compliance obligations that Zebracorp might have.
content.justification: Supports the requirement for suppliers to provide OSS license details.

content.plain_text: Suppliers of OSS components should provide the complete open source software license text in editable format, and for any OSS requiring redistribution, the necessary tools and information to build the source code.
content.expert_insight: This specifies the format and additional support required from suppliers for certain OSS, ensuring Zebracorp can meet its own compliance and redistribution obligations.
content.justification: Facilitates Zebracorp's compliance and redistribution obligations.
content.implication_company: Enables Zebracorp to comply with OSS licenses and, if necessary, redistribute source code.

content.text: Suppliers of OSS components should be able to also provide: (i) the entire open source software license text in editable text form; and (ii) for any open source software requiring redistribution as part of its license terms, necessary tools and information to build the source code.

content.verbatim_text: “The [Licensor] represents and warrants to [ZEBRACORP] that no open source software in whole or in part is incorporated into any part of the [Products], save for the open source software disclosed by [ZEBRACORP] and listed in Appendix X (Disclosure) of this [Agreement], unless such open source software has been disclosed in advance to [ZEBRACORP] and subsequently accepted by [ZEBRACORP]. Such disclosure shall include open source component and component version and license and license version for each open source component.”
content.plain_text: An example disclosure clause states that the Licensor warrants no undisclosed open source software is incorporated into products. Any OSS must be disclosed (component, version, license, license version) and accepted by Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This example clause is critical for Zebracorp, providing a strong contractual mechanism to ensure full disclosure and control over OSS components, protecting against hidden 'viral' risks.
content.justification: Provides a contractual template for ensuring supplier disclosure and Zebracorp acceptance of OSS components.
content.implication_company: Strong contractual protection against undisclosed or unapproved OSS, reducing IP risk.
content.implication_supplier: Creates a strict warranty and disclosure obligation for the supplier.
