content.text: “The [Licensor] represents and warrants to [ZEBRACORP] that no open source software in whole or in part is incorporated into any part of the [Products], save for the open source software disclosed by [ZEBRACORP] and listed in Appendix X (Disclosure) of this [Agreement], unless such open source software has been disclosed in advance to [ZEBRACORP] and subsequently accepted by [ZEBRACORP]. Such disclosure shall include open source component and component version and license and license version for each open source component.”

content.verbatim_text: The standard warranties and indemnities should apply to the OSS code, unless Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge.
content.plain_text: Standard warranties and indemnities should apply to open source software code, unless Zebracorp acquires the code for free.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates Zebracorp's position on supplier liability: if Zebracorp pays for the software, it expects the same protections for OSS components as for proprietary ones.
content.conditions: OSS code is not obtained free of charge.
content.justification: Ensures commercial protections for paid products.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains strong warranty and indemnity protections for paid software.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier must provide standard warranties and indemnities for OSS in paid products.

content.text: The standard warranties and indemnities should apply to the OSS code, unless Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge.

content.verbatim_text: We can accept that OSS code is subject to respective OSS license terms, but the supplier should ensure that those license terms are consistent with the licenses that the supplier has granted to Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can accept OSS code being subject to its own license terms, provided the supplier ensures those terms are consistent with the licenses granted by the supplier to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This balances acceptance of OSS licensing realities with the need to protect Zebracorp's negotiated rights. The onus is on the supplier to manage consistency.
content.justification: Ensures that Zebracorp's rights from the supplier are not undermined by OSS license terms.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's contractual rights are preserved.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier is responsible for ensuring compatibility between OSS licenses and their grants to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Legal Scout Analysis
content.text: We can accept that OSS code is subject to respective OSS license terms, but the supplier should ensure that those license terms are consistent with the licenses that the supplier has granted to Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: “The open source software is subject to the license terms of the open source license. Should there be any unresolved conflict between any term or condition contained in this [Agreement] and any terms or conditions of any such open source license(s), the terms and conditions of the applicable open source license(s) shall supersede the license grant or restrictions herein. However, nothing in the open source software license shall limit or restrict [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under this Agreement, or the [Licensor]’s obligations including but not limited to any warranties or indemnity obligations under this [Agreement]. For clarification, nothing in this [Agreement] shall further be construed to limit [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under the applicable open source license terms.”
content.plain_text: An example provision states that OSS is subject to its license terms. If there's an unresolved conflict between the main agreement and an OSS license, the OSS license supersedes only the license grant or restrictions. Crucially, the OSS license cannot limit Zebracorp's rights or the Licensor's obligations (including warranties/indemnity) under the main agreement. The agreement also doesn't limit Zebracorp's rights under the OSS license.
content.expert_insight: This is a highly sophisticated and critical clause. It acknowledges OSS license precedence for the 'license grant' while rigorously safeguarding Zebracorp's broader contractual rights and the supplier's obligations, particularly for warranties and indemnities. It's a strong protective measure.
content.justification: Provides a comprehensive contractual framework for managing conflicts between OSS licenses and the main agreement, prioritizing Zebracorp's protections.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp's fundamental rights and supplier obligations (especially warranties/indemnities) are preserved, even when OSS license terms take precedence on specific license grants.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's obligations remain fully intact, despite any OSS license terms.
content.source_insight: Legal Scout Analysis

content.justification: Supports Zebracorp's position on supplier liability for products containing OSS.

content.verbatim_text: Open source software (OSS) and free software generally refer to software, which is free from any onerous licensing restrictions, and which is available for any person to view, edit, and/or change code.
content.plain_text: Open source software (OSS) and free software are defined as software that is free from restrictive licensing and allows anyone to view, edit, or change its code.
content.expert_insight: This provides a foundational understanding of what constitutes open source software, emphasizing its accessibility and freedom from 'onerous' restrictions.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Open source software (OSS) and free software generally refer to software, which is free from any onerous licensing restrictions, and which is available for any person to view, edit, and/or change code.

content.verbatim_text: A common misunderstanding is to assume that open source code is public domain and free for anyone to use. However, open source code is, in fact, copyrighted and relies heavily to copyright protection.
content.plain_text: It's a common misconception that open source code is public domain; in reality, it is copyrighted and protected.
content.expert_insight: This insight corrects a critical misunderstanding, highlighting that despite being 'open,' OSS is still subject to copyright law, which necessitates proper licensing for use.
content.justification: Clarifies a common misconception about OSS legal status.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must understand that OSS is copyrighted and not freely usable without a license.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must also be aware of the copyrighted nature of OSS components they use or provide.
content.source_insight: The text directly states this as a 'common misunderstanding'.
content.text: A common misunderstanding is to assume that open source code is public domain and free for anyone to use. However, open source code is, in fact, copyrighted and relies heavily to copyright protection.

content.verbatim_text: As with any other copyrighted work (such as in e.g. Microsoft’s Office Pack), you need a license from the copyright holder to use the code.
content.plain_text: To use open source code, a license from the copyright holder is required, similar to any other copyrighted software.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a fundamental legal requirement: even for open source software, a license is mandatory for use, just like proprietary software. Non-compliance can lead to copyright infringement.
content.conditions: Using open source code.
content.justification: Open source code is copyrighted, therefore a license is required for its use.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must obtain and adhere to licenses for all OSS used.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must ensure they have valid licenses for any OSS they incorporate and provide to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Directly stated as a requirement for using copyrighted work.
content.text: As with any other copyrighted work (such as in e.g. Microsoft’s Office Pack), you need a license from the copyright holder to use the code.

content.verbatim_text: It is good to keep in mind that only by being in compliance with the OSS license terms, we have rights to use the copyrighted OSS software.
content.plain_text: The right to use copyrighted open source software is contingent upon compliance with its specific license terms.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes that merely having a license isn't enough; strict adherence to all license terms is crucial to legally exercise the right to use OSS. Any breach can invalidate the right to use.
content.conditions: To have rights to use copyrighted OSS software.
content.justification: Compliance with license terms is the basis for legal use of copyrighted software.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure full compliance with all OSS license terms to avoid legal issues.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must ensure their use and distribution of OSS comply with all applicable license terms, as this directly affects Zebracorp's rights.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states 'only by being in compliance...we have rights'.
content.text: It is good to keep in mind that only by being in compliance with the OSS license terms, we have rights to use the copyrighted OSS software.

content.verbatim_text: Most open source software licenses grant licensees somewhat free right to copy, modify and redistribute source code. However, these licenses may also impose obligations such as for example a requirement that modifications to the code that are distributed must be made available in source code form, requirement to include copyright notices, requirements on how software can be redistributed, or requirement to freely release the combined software code (incorporating the open source code).
content.plain_text: While most OSS licenses allow copying, modification, and redistribution, they often include obligations like making modified code available in source form, including copyright notices, specifying redistribution methods, or requiring the release of combined software code.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the dual nature of OSS licenses: offering significant freedoms while simultaneously imposing specific obligations. Understanding these obligations is key to avoiding license violations.
content.justification: Provides context on the typical scope of OSS licenses, including both rights and common obligations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to be aware of these potential obligations when using or modifying OSS, especially regarding redistribution.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be fully aware of and adhere to these obligations for any OSS they integrate into products supplied to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text describes common features of OSS licenses.
content.text: Most open source software licenses grant licensees somewhat free right to copy, modify and redistribute source code. However, these licenses may also impose obligations such as for example a requirement that modifications to the code that are distributed must be made available in source code form, requirement to include copyright notices, requirements on how software can be redistributed, or requirement to freely release the combined software code (incorporating the open source code).

content.verbatim_text: Open source software that imposes requirements on distribution are generally known as ‘strong open source license’ or so called ‘copyleft’ open source license.
content.plain_text: A 'strong open source license' or 'copyleft' license refers to open source software licenses that impose specific requirements on how the software can be distributed.
content.expert_insight: This defines a critical category of OSS licenses ('copyleft') which have significant implications due to their reciprocal nature, often requiring derivative works to be licensed under the same terms.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Open source software that imposes requirements on distribution are generally known as ‘strong open source license’ or so called ‘copyleft’ open source license.

content.verbatim_text: A typical example of such copyleft or strong OSS is GNU General Public License (GPL), which is perhaps the most widely used open source software. Under the GPL license, the derived works can only be distributed under the same license terms.
content.plain_text: The GNU General Public License (GPL) is a widely used example of a copyleft license, requiring derived works to be distributed under the same license terms.
content.expert_insight: This provides a concrete example (GPL) of a copyleft license and highlights its key 'share-alike' characteristic, which is crucial for understanding its impact on proprietary code integration.
content.justification: Illustrates the definition of copyleft licenses with a well-known example.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must be extremely cautious when using GPL-licensed code, as it can force proprietary software to become open source.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers using GPL code must understand its implications for any derived works or combined software they provide to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly gives GPL as a 'typical example' and describes its core term.
content.text: A typical example of such copyleft or strong OSS is GNU General Public License (GPL), which is perhaps the most widely used open source software. Under the GPL license, the derived works can only be distributed under the same license terms.

content.verbatim_text: In some instances Zebracorp proprietary software can be ‘contaminated’ with open source code. This contamination occurs when software created from open source code or containing open source code must be made freely available according to the terms of the original open source license. This so called viral effect means that if a piece of in e.g. GPL code is used in a work that includes proprietary code, then this resulting work must become open under the GPL in its entirety.
content.plain_text: Proprietary software can be 'contaminated' by open source code, meaning that if proprietary software incorporates or is derived from OSS, particularly GPL code, the entire resulting work might be required to become freely available under the original open source license (the 'viral effect').
content.expert_insight: This defines the 'contamination' or 'viral effect' of certain OSS licenses, which is a critical risk for companies developing proprietary software. It highlights how a small piece of OSS can legally mandate the open-sourcing of an entire product.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In some instances Zebracorp proprietary software can be ‘contaminated’ with open source code. This contamination occurs when software created from open source code or containing open source code must be made freely available according to the terms of the original open source license. This so called viral effect means that if a piece of in e.g. GPL code is used in a work that includes proprietary code, then this resulting work must become open under the GPL in its entirety.

content.verbatim_text: In an extreme case scenario a minor piece of open source code contaminates an entire software bundle rendering it legally impossible to hide its source code.
content.plain_text: In extreme cases, even a small portion of open source code can 'contaminate' an entire software bundle, making it legally impossible to keep its source code proprietary.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the significant risk of the 'viral effect,' illustrating how even minor OSS inclusion can lead to major legal and business consequences for proprietary software.
content.justification: Provides an extreme example to highlight the severity of the 'viral effect'.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp faces the risk of losing control over its proprietary code if 'contamination' occurs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be extremely careful to avoid such contamination when integrating OSS into products for Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text describes an 'extreme case scenario'.
content.text: In an extreme case scenario a minor piece of open source code contaminates an entire software bundle rendering it legally impossible to hide its source code.

content.verbatim_text: Generally speaking open source software that has reciprocity or share-alike requirements (i.e. that require all distributed copies or/and modified versions of a work to be free of charge or freely available to be modified), are problematic.
content.plain_text: Open source software with reciprocity or 'share-alike' requirements (mandating distributed copies or modified versions to be free or freely modifiable) is generally considered problematic.
content.expert_insight: This categorizes 'share-alike' OSS as 'problematic' due to its potential to force proprietary code into the open source domain, advising caution for companies like Zebracorp.
content.justification: Identifies a category of OSS licenses that pose specific challenges due to their reciprocal nature.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be wary of using OSS with reciprocity or share-alike requirements due to potential 'viral' effects.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should avoid incorporating problematic OSS into products provided to Zebracorp, or at least disclose it fully and manage the risks.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states these types of licenses 'are problematic'.
content.text: Generally speaking open source software that has reciprocity or share-alike requirements (i.e. that require all distributed copies or/and modified versions of a work to be free of charge or freely available to be modified), are problematic.

content.verbatim_text: This is in contrast to so called ‘permissive open source software’ or ‘flexible open source license’ in e.g. Apache which has minimal requirements on how the software can be redistributed and which usually permit the re-distributor to combine the licensed material with other license terms, potentially adding further restrictions to a derived work.
content.plain_text: 'Permissive open source software' or 'flexible open source licenses' (like Apache) have minimal redistribution requirements and allow combining licensed material with other license terms, potentially adding further restrictions to derived works.
content.expert_insight: This defines 'permissive' OSS, contrasting it with 'copyleft' and highlighting its flexibility, which is generally more favorable for integration into proprietary products as it allows for adding restrictions.

content.verbatim_text: Because of the nature of OSS, any modifications to the any OSS code must be considered carefully by Zebracorp IPR.

content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the need for internal legal review before modifying OSS, especially given the complex and varied licensing terms that can impact intellectual property rights.

content.implication_company: Zebracorp must implement a robust review process for any OSS modifications.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should also carefully consider and disclose any modifications they make to OSS components provided to Zebracorp.

content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware of this limitation when considering GPL components for Zebracorp products.

content.expert_insight: This is a crucial mitigation strategy: while accepting the OSS license's precedence on the grant, Zebracorp must safeguard its broader contractual rights, especially those negotiated with the supplier.
content.conditions: When OSS license terms take precedence over the mutual agreement's license grant.
content.justification: To protect Zebracorp's negotiated rights beyond the specific OSS license grant.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure this protective clause is included in agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must accept this clarification, ensuring their OSS integration does not inadvertently diminish Zebracorp's rights.
content.source_insight: Direct instruction: 'we should specifically state that nothing...will restrict the rights granted to Zebracorp'.
content.text: In that case, we should specifically state that nothing contained in those open source license terms will restrict the rights granted to Zebracorp under the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: So while we accept the license restrictions that come with the OSS, the supplier of the code should make sure that those restrictions do not conflict with the licenses and rights that it has granted to Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: While Zebracorp accepts OSS license restrictions, the supplier must ensure these restrictions do not conflict with the licenses and rights granted by the supplier to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This places the onus on the supplier to reconcile any conflicts between OSS license terms and their direct contractual obligations to Zebracorp, ensuring Zebracorp's received rights are not undermined.
content.conditions: Accepting OSS license restrictions.
content.justification: The supplier is responsible for the overall product and its components, including ensuring consistency of rights granted.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp relies on the supplier to manage this consistency.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers have an obligation to verify that OSS license terms do not create conflicts with their contractual grants to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Direct instruction regarding supplier responsibility.
content.text: So while we accept the license restrictions that come with the OSS, the supplier of the code should make sure that those restrictions do not conflict with the licenses and rights that it has granted to Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: As for all terms and conditions other than license terms, our position should be that the terms of our mutual agreement will apply also to the OSS components of a particular product. This means that in e.g. the IPR indemnity that protects us against third party infringement claims applies also the OSS components.
content.plain_text: For all terms and conditions other than the license grant, Zebracorp's position is that the mutual agreement's terms, including IPR indemnity, apply to OSS components.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies Zebracorp's stance: while the OSS license might govern the grant, all other critical contractual protections (like IPR indemnity, warranties) from the main agreement must extend to the OSS components. This shields Zebracorp from risks associated with OSS.
content.conditions: Regarding terms and conditions other than license grants for OSS components.
content.justification: To ensure comprehensive protection for Zebracorp, even when OSS components are involved.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must enforce this position in negotiations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must accept that their contractual obligations, such as IPR indemnity, apply to all components, including OSS.
content.source_insight: The text states 'our position should be that the terms of our mutual agreement will apply also to the OSS components'.
content.text: As for all terms and conditions other than license terms, our position should be that the terms of our mutual agreement will apply also to the OSS components of a particular product. This means that in e.g. the IPR indemnity that protects us against third party infringement claims applies also the OSS components.

content.verbatim_text: The supplier’s election to incorporate OSS components into its products should not limit the warranties and indemnities available to Zebracorp under the agreement.
content.plain_text: A supplier's decision to use OSS components in its products must not reduce the warranties and indemnities Zebracorp is entitled to under the agreement.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a critical principle: suppliers cannot use OSS as an excuse to reduce their liability or contractual obligations. The responsibility for the entire product, including OSS parts, remains with the supplier.
content.conditions: Supplier incorporates OSS components into products.
content.justification: Zebracorp should receive full protection for the entire product, regardless of its internal components.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure this clause is upheld in agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must understand that using OSS does not diminish their warranty and indemnity obligations.
content.source_insight: Directly states what 'should not limit'.
content.text: The supplier’s election to incorporate OSS components into its products should not limit the warranties and indemnities available to Zebracorp under the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: The license terms of the OSS generally do not provide any protection against third party IPR infringement claims.
content.plain_text: Open source software license terms typically do not offer protection against third-party intellectual property infringement claims.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a significant gap in OSS licenses: they generally don't include indemnification for IPR infringement, underscoring why supplier-provided indemnities are crucial for Zebracorp.
content.justification: Explains a common limitation of OSS licenses regarding IPR protection.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp cannot rely on OSS licenses for IPR infringement protection and must seek it from the supplier.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must recognize this gap and be prepared to provide IPR indemnities for OSS components.
content.source_insight: The text states 'generally do not provide any protection'.
content.text: The license terms of the OSS generally do not provide any protection against third party IPR infringement claims.

content.verbatim_text: Having the OSS license terms determine the indemnity and warranty terms is only acceptable if Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge, but it should be challenged if the OSS is sold or licensed to Zebracorp as part of a product or solution that has a price tag.
content.plain_text: Allowing OSS license terms to dictate indemnity and warranty is only acceptable if Zebracorp receives the code free of charge; otherwise, it should be challenged, especially if part of a priced product.
content.expert_insight: This sets a clear boundary: if Zebracorp is paying for a product that includes OSS, it should not accept reduced indemnity or warranty terms based on the OSS license. The supplier must bear the full responsibility.
content.conditions: OSS license terms determining indemnity and warranty terms.
content.justification: When paying for a product, Zebracorp expects full commercial protections, which OSS licenses typically do not provide.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must challenge any attempts to limit indemnity/warranty based on OSS if the product is not free.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers cannot use OSS as a reason to reduce indemnity/warranty for priced products.
content.source_insight: Direct instruction on when it is 'acceptable' or 'should be challenged'.
content.text: Having the OSS license terms determine the indemnity and warranty terms is only acceptable if Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge, but it should be challenged if the OSS is sold or licensed to Zebracorp as part of a product or solution that has a price tag.

content.verbatim_text: The supplier should not get the benefit of reduced liability as a result of using OSS in its products.
content.plain_text: Suppliers should not benefit from reduced liability simply because they use open source software in their products.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces the principle that incorporating OSS does not absolve the supplier of their full contractual liabilities. The supplier remains accountable for the entire product.
content.conditions: Supplier uses OSS in its products.
content.justification: The supplier is providing a commercial product and should bear full responsibility for it.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure this principle is maintained in agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must accept full liability for products containing OSS.
content.source_insight: Direct statement of what 'should not' happen.
content.text: The supplier should not get the benefit of reduced liability as a result of using OSS in its products.

content.verbatim_text: In order to give Zebracorp and its end customers the opportunity to review any restrictions contained in the license terms, the suppliers should at a minimum be required to provide details of any open source software included in any of the deliverables provided to us as well as details on the applicable license terms (which also include the respective version numbers of these license terms).
content.plain_text: Suppliers must, at a minimum, provide Zebracorp with details of all open source software included in deliverables, including applicable license terms and their version numbers, to allow review of restrictions.
content.expert_insight: This sets a fundamental requirement for transparency from suppliers, enabling Zebracorp and its customers to understand and comply with OSS obligations and assess potential risks.
content.conditions: Suppliers providing deliverables containing OSS.
content.justification: To allow Zebracorp and its end customers to review restrictions and comply with license terms.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must enforce this disclosure requirement.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are obligated to provide comprehensive details about all OSS components and their licenses.
content.source_insight: Stated as a 'minimum' requirement for suppliers under 'Zebracorp Preferred Position'.
content.text: In order to give Zebracorp and its end customers the opportunity to review any restrictions contained in the license terms, the suppliers should at a minimum be required to provide details of any open source software included in any of the deliverables provided to us as well as details on the applicable license terms (which also include the respective version numbers of these license terms).

content.verbatim_text: Information on license terms is also important since the use and distribution of open source software often requires that the open source license is passed onwards to the end users of the software.
content.plain_text: Providing license term information is crucial because OSS use and distribution often necessitate passing the license to end-users.
content.expert_insight: This provides a key justification for the disclosure requirement: many OSS licenses mandate 'pass-through' obligations, making it essential for Zebracorp to have this information for its own compliance and that of its customers.
content.justification: To ensure compliance with pass-through requirements of OSS licenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs this information to fulfill its own obligations to end-users.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' disclosure helps Zebracorp meet its downstream obligations.
content.source_insight: Explains why 'Information on license terms is also important'.
content.text: Information on license terms is also important since the use and distribution of open source software often requires that the open source license is passed onwards to the end users of the software.

content.verbatim_text: Suppliers of OSS components should be able to also provide: (i) the entire open source software license text in editable text form; and (ii) for any open source software requiring redistribution as part of its license terms, necessary tools and information to build the source code.
content.plain_text: Suppliers of OSS components should provide: (i) the full license text in editable format; and (ii) for redistribution-required OSS, tools and information to build the source code.
content.expert_insight: These are practical requirements that enable Zebracorp to fully comply with OSS license terms, particularly for 'copyleft' licenses that mandate source code availability and build instructions.
content.conditions: Suppliers providing OSS components.
content.justification: To enable Zebracorp to comply with OSS license terms, especially redistribution requirements.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs these items to ensure compliance and manage OSS effectively.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be prepared to provide these specific items for OSS components.
content.source_insight: Stated as additional provisions suppliers 'should be able to also provide'.
content.text: Suppliers of OSS components should be able to also provide: (i) the entire open source software license text in editable text form; and (ii) for any open source software requiring redistribution as part of its license terms, necessary tools and information to build the source code.

content.verbatim_text: “The [Licensor] represents and warrants to [ZEBRACORP] that no open source software in whole or in part is incorporated into any part of the [Products], save for the open source software disclosed by [ZEBRACORP] and listed in Appendix X (Disclosure) of this [Agreement], unless such open source software has been disclosed in advance to [ZEBRACORP] and subsequently accepted by [ZEBRACORP]. Such disclosure shall include open source component and component version and license and license version for each open source component.”
content.plain_text: An example disclosure clause states that the Licensor warrants no undisclosed OSS is incorporated into products. Any accepted OSS must be listed in an appendix, with disclosure including component, version, license, and license version.
content.expert_insight: This provides a template for a contractual clause ensuring transparency and control over OSS components. It shifts the burden of disclosure and compliance onto the supplier.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of a contractual clause reflecting Zebracorp's preferred position on OSS disclosure.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this as a template for its agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect to see and comply with such disclosure clauses.
content.source_insight: Explicitly labeled as 'an example of disclosure clause'.
content.text: “The [Licensor] represents and warrants to [ZEBRACORP] that no open source software in whole or in part is incorporated into any part of the [Products], save for the open source software disclosed by [ZEBRACORP] and listed in Appendix X (Disclosure) of this [Agreement], unless such open source software has been disclosed in advance to [ZEBRACORP] and subsequently accepted by [ZEBRACORP]. Such disclosure shall include open source component and component version and license and license version for each open source component.”

content.verbatim_text: The standard warranties and indemnities should apply to the OSS code, unless Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge.
content.plain_text: Standard warranties and indemnities must apply to open source software code, unless Zebracorp acquires the code without cost.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates that if Zebracorp is paying for a product, the supplier's standard warranties and indemnities must cover the OSS components, removing the 'free' software excuse for reduced liability.
content.conditions: Zebracorp obtains OSS code as part of a paid product/solution.
content.justification: To ensure Zebracorp receives full commercial protections for all components of a purchased product.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure this is stipulated in agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must provide standard warranties and indemnities for OSS components within paid products.
content.source_insight: Direct statement of what 'should apply' with a condition.
content.text: The standard warranties and indemnities should apply to the OSS code, unless Zebracorp obtains the OSS code free of charge.

content.verbatim_text: We can accept that OSS code is subject to respective OSS license terms, but the supplier should ensure that those license terms are consistent with the licenses that the supplier has granted to Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can accept that OSS code is governed by its own license terms, but the supplier must ensure these terms are consistent with the licenses granted by the supplier to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This balances acceptance of OSS license realities with the protection of Zebracorp's negotiated rights. The supplier is made responsible for ensuring no conflict arises.
content.conditions: Accepting OSS code subject to its license terms.
content.justification: To prevent conflicts between OSS license terms and the supplier's grants to Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept OSS terms but relies on the supplier for consistency checks.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are responsible for verifying that OSS license terms do not undermine their grants to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: States what 'we can accept' and what the 'supplier should ensure'.
content.text: We can accept that OSS code is subject to respective OSS license terms, but the supplier should ensure that those license terms are consistent with the licenses that the supplier has granted to Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: “The open source software is subject to the license terms of the open source license. Should there be any unresolved conflict between any term or condition contained in this [Agreement] and any terms or conditions of any such open source license(s), the terms and conditions of the applicable open source license(s) shall supersede the license grant or restrictions herein. However, nothing in the open source software license shall limit or restrict [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under this Agreement, or the [Licensor]’s obligations including but not limited to any warranties or indemnity obligations under this [Agreement]. For clarification, nothing in this [Agreement] shall further be construed to limit [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under the applicable open source license terms.”
content.plain_text: An example provision states that OSS is subject to its own license, which supersedes conflicting license grants in the main agreement. However, it explicitly clarifies that the OSS license does not limit Zebracorp's rights or the Licensor's obligations (e.g., warranties, indemnities) under the main agreement.
content.expert_insight: This provides a robust contractual clause to manage the interplay between OSS licenses and the main agreement. It prioritizes the OSS license for the 'grant' but firmly protects Zebracorp's broader rights and supplier obligations.
content.justification: Provides a contractual example to implement the guideline regarding conflicting terms and Zebracorp's rights.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this provision to protect its interests when incorporating OSS.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect such clauses and ensure compliance.
content.source_insight: Explicitly introduced as 'an example provision below'.
content.text: “The open source software is subject to the license terms of the open source license. Should there be any unresolved conflict between any term or condition contained in this [Agreement] and any terms or conditions of any such open source license(s), the terms and conditions of the applicable open source license(s) shall supersede the license grant or restrictions herein. However, nothing in the open source software license shall limit or restrict [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under this Agreement, or the [Licensor]’s obligations including but not limited to any warranties or indemnity obligations under this [Agreement]. For clarification, nothing in this [Agreement] shall further be construed to limit [ZEBRACORP]’s rights under the applicable open source license terms.”

content.verbatim_text: The vendor of a commercial product should accept responsibility for the entire product even if it contains OSS code.
content.plain_text: Vendors of commercial products should be fully responsible for the entire product, including any open source software components.
content.expert_insight: This is a core argument for Zebracorp's position, asserting that the commercial vendor, not Zebracorp, should bear the ultimate responsibility for all components of a product it sells.
content.justification: Supports Zebracorp's position on supplier responsibility for OSS.
content.implication_company: This argument strengthens Zebracorp's negotiation stance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand this fundamental expectation of responsibility.
content.source_insight: Listed under 'Arguments in support of Zebracorp’s position'.
content.text: The vendor of a commercial product should accept responsibility for the entire product even if it contains OSS code.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp performs checks on all OSS components and requires details on these components in order to complete the checks.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp conducts checks on all OSS components and needs detailed information about them to perform these checks.
content.expert_insight: This justifies the requirement for detailed OSS disclosure, as Zebracorp has an internal process to vet these components for compliance and risk.
content.justification: Supports the requirement for suppliers to provide detailed OSS information.
content.implication_company: Highlights Zebracorp's internal due diligence processes.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' cooperation with disclosure is essential for Zebracorp's internal checks.
content.source_insight: Listed under 'Arguments in support of Zebracorp’s position'.
content.text: Zebracorp performs checks on all OSS components and requires details on these components in order to complete the checks.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp needs detailed information on the OSS components and the applicable license terms in order to be able to comply with those terms and, where required, to distribute these onwards to its customers.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp requires detailed information on OSS components and their license terms to ensure compliance and facilitate onward distribution to customers when necessary.
content.expert_insight: This argument underscores the operational necessity of disclosure, as Zebracorp must manage its own compliance and potentially pass on OSS obligations to its downstream customers.
content.justification: Supports the requirement for suppliers to provide detailed OSS information.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs this information for its own and its customers' compliance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' disclosure directly enables Zebracorp's compliance and distribution needs.
content.source_insight: Listed under 'Arguments in support of Zebracorp’s position'.
content.text: Zebracorp needs detailed information on the OSS components and the applicable license terms in order to be able to comply with those terms and, where required, to distribute these onwards to its customers.

content.verbatim_text: Having no information on the applicable open source software license terms may leave Zebracorp exposed to copyright infringement, injunction/sales ban, suits and/or loss of control over Zebracorp’s own proprietary code.
content.plain_text: Lack of information on OSS license terms can expose Zebracorp to significant risks, including copyright infringement, sales bans, lawsuits, and loss of control over its proprietary code.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the severe consequences of inadequate OSS management, providing a strong rationale for demanding full disclosure and adherence to best practices.
content.justification: Explains the risks associated with insufficient OSS license information.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp faces substantial legal and commercial risks if it lacks OSS license information.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' failure to disclose OSS information directly exposes Zebracorp to these risks.
content.source_insight: Listed under 'Arguments in support of Zebracorp’s position'.
content.text: Having no information on the applicable open source software license terms may leave Zebracorp exposed to copyright infringement, injunction/sales ban, suits and/or loss of control over Zebracorp’s own proprietary code.

content.verbatim_text: Depending on the circumstances we may require the following or substantially similar covenants from the supplier: “To the knowledge of the [Supplier], no proprietary intellectual property is, in whole or in part, subject to the provision of any open source or other type of license agreement or distribution model that: requires the distribution or making available of the source code for any proprietary intellectual property, prohibits or limits [Party] from charging a fee or receiving consideration in connection with sublicensing or distributing any proprietary intellectual property, grants any right to or otherwise allows anyone to decompile, disassemble or otherwise reverse-engineer any proprietary intellectual property, or requires the licensing of any proprietary intellectual property for the purpose of making derivative works.”
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may require supplier covenants warranting that no proprietary IP is subject to OSS licenses that: require source code distribution, prohibit charging fees for sublicensing/distribution, grant reverse-engineering rights, or require licensing for derivative works.
content.expert_insight: This outlines key contractual protections Zebracorp may seek from suppliers to prevent 'viral' effects and maintain control over its proprietary IP, especially when OSS is involved.
content.conditions: Circumstances warranting specific covenants from the supplier.
content.justification: To protect Zebracorp's proprietary intellectual property from the 'viral' effects of certain OSS licenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should consider including these covenants in agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be able to provide these warranties regarding their proprietary IP not being subject to restrictive OSS terms.
content.source_insight: Introduced as covenants Zebracorp 'may require'.
content.text: Depending on the circumstances we may require the following or substantially similar covenants from the supplier: “To the knowledge of the [Supplier], no proprietary intellectual property is, in whole or in part, subject to the provision of any open source or other type of license agreement or distribution model that: requires the distribution or making available of the source code for any proprietary intellectual property, prohibits or limits [Party] from charging a fee or receiving consideration in connection with sublicensing or distributing any proprietary intellectual property, grants any right to or otherwise allows anyone to decompile, disassemble or otherwise reverse-engineer any proprietary intellectual property, or requires the licensing of any proprietary intellectual property for the purpose of making derivative works.”

content.verbatim_text: Note that above covenants should always be required in those cases where the supplier is for whatever reason unable to provide the details of the OSS components and the applicable license terms.
content.plain_text: The aforementioned covenants must always be required if the supplier cannot provide details of OSS components and their license terms.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a mandatory fallback position: if transparency is lacking, Zebracorp must secure strong contractual guarantees to mitigate the unknown risks associated with undisclosed OSS.
content.conditions: Supplier is unable to provide details of OSS components and applicable license terms.
content.justification: To mitigate risks when the supplier cannot provide necessary transparency regarding OSS components.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must enforce these covenants in the absence of full OSS disclosure.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers unable to provide OSS details will face a mandatory requirement for these restrictive covenants.
content.source_insight: Direct instruction: 'above covenants should always be required'.
content.text: Note that above covenants should always be required in those cases where the supplier is for whatever reason unable to provide the details of the OSS components and the applicable license terms.
